summary: This is a Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) report titled 'Criminal Victimization, 2020' analyzing data from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS). It details trends in violent and property crime rates from 2016 to 2020, with a focus on the 2019-2020 period and the impact of COVID-19 on survey methodology. The document is a general statistical publication and contains no direct information about the Epstein case. This document is a Bureau of Justice Statistics report titled 'Criminal Victimization, 2020', presenting data from the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS). It analyzes trends in crime reporting and victimization rates from 2019 to 2020, with a focus on violent crime, property crime, and specific categories like intimate partner violence. The document contains no direct references to the Epstein case, individuals, or related events. This document is a technical appendix and methodology section from the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) report 'Criminal Victimization, 2020', published in October 2021. It details the survey methodology, definitions, weighting procedures, and statistical measures used in the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS), including specific definitions for measuring rape and sexual assault. It contains no direct references to the Epstein case. This document is a statistical appendix from the Bureau of Justice Statistics report 'Criminal Victimization, 2020', published in October 2021. It contains detailed tables with standard errors and estimates for national crime victimization data from 2016-2020, focusing on violent and property crimes, reporting rates, and demographic breakdowns. It appears to be included in the Epstein document release as contextual or reference material, not directly related to the case.

events.title: COVID-19 NCVS Field Operations Suspension
events.description: The Bureau of Justice Statistics, in coordination with the U.S. Census Bureau, suspended all incoming sample interviews for the National Crime Victimization Survey and shifted returning sample interviews to telephone calls due to COVID-19 risks.

events.title: Resumption of Modified NCVS Field Visits
events.description: Modified personal visits for the NCVS resumed in some geographic areas for returning sample households, based on federal, state, and local guidance.

events.title: Full Resumption of Modified NCVS Field Operations
events.description: Personal visits for the NCVS resumed for both incoming and returning sample households under modified procedures, subject to guidance.

events.title: Publication of Criminal Victimization Report
events.description: The Bureau of Justice Statistics published its annual report 'Criminal Victimization, 2020'.

keyFacts: The document is a general U.S. Department of Justice statistical report on national crime victimization trends for 2020 and contains no information specific to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or his case.

The report states the total violent victimization rate declined 22% from 2019 to 2020, driven by a decline in assault rates; rates of rape/sexual assault and robbery did not show a statistically significant change.
The property crime victimization rate declined for the second consecutive year, with decreases in burglary and trespassing driving the overall reduction.
The report details significant methodological impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS), including suspended interviews and shifted data collection modes.
The report compares crime data from the NCVS with the FBI's Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) program, noting differences in methodology and scope between the two measures.
The report shows a statistically significant decline in the percentage of intimate partner violence reported to police from 58% in 2019 to 41% in 2020.
The rate of violent victimization reported to police declined from 8.6 to 6.6 victimizations per 1,000 persons age 12 or older from 2019 to 2020.
The rate of violent victimization against youth ages 12 to 17 declined by 51% from 2019 to 2020.
The number of violent victimizations in the U.S. that involved a firearm declined 27%, from 481,950 in 2019 to 350,460 in 2020.
The document is a general statistical report from the Bureau of Justice Statistics and contains no information specific to the Jeffrey Epstein case, its victims, associates, or investigations.
This document is a standard BJS statistical methodology report and contains no information related to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or his case.
The text focuses entirely on the technical definitions, survey procedures, and weighting methods for the National Crime Victimization Survey (NCVS).
It includes detailed definitions for how the NCVS measures and classifies crimes, including rape and sexual assault.
The document explains statistical concepts like victimization rates, incident rates, prevalence rates, standard errors, and confidence intervals.
The file name (EFTA00156952.pdf) and its placement in a dataset related to the Epstein case appears to be a clerical or archival error, as the content is unrelated.
This document is a statistical appendix from a U.S. Department of Justice report on national crime victimization trends from 2016-2020.
It contains no direct references to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, victims, properties, or specific case events.
The document's inclusion in the Epstein case file release is likely incidental, possibly as background material or part of a larger document collection.
The data focuses on aggregate national statistics for crimes like rape/sexual assault, robbery, and assault, broken down by demographics and location.
The report was authored and produced by staff of the Bureau of Justice Statistics in October 2021.
